sub_topic: Schwarz reflection principle and its applications
message_1: Consider the function $f(z) = z^2 - 2z + 1$ defined on the upper half plane $H = \{z \in \mathbb{C}: \text{Im}(z) > 0\}$. Suppose that $f$ can be extended analytically to the real line $\mathbb{R}$ except for the point $x = 1$. Use the Schwarz reflection principle to extend $f$ analytically to the whole complex plane $\mathbb{C}$. What is the extended function of $f(z)$ for all $z\in\mathbb{C}$?
message_2:
To apply the Schwarz reflection principle, we first need to find an analytic function that agrees with $f(z)$ on the real line except for the point $x=1$. We can do this by considering the function $g(z) = (z-1)^2$. Notice that $g(z) = f(z)$ for all $z \in \mathbb{R}$ except for $x=1$. 

Now, we can define the reflection of $g(z)$ across the real axis as $g^*(z) = g(\overline{z}) = (\overline{z}-1)^2$. Since $g(z)$ is analytic on the upper half plane and continuous on the real line, the Schwarz reflection principle states that the function $h(z) = g(z)$ for $z \in H$ and $h(z) = g^*(z)$ for $z \in \overline{H}$ is analytic on the whole complex plane except for the point $x=1$.

Thus, the extended function of $f(z)$ for all $z \in \mathbb{C}$ is given by:

$$
h(z) = \begin{cases}
(z-1)^2 & \text{if } \text{Im}(z) > 0 \\
(\overline{z}-1)^2 & \text{if } \text{Im}(z) < 0
\end{cases}
$$

This function is analytic on the whole complex plane except for the point $x=1$.
